On Sun, 26 Sep 2004 21:23:37 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Hi Mike, welcome to the group.
> 
> Mike Woodhouse wrote:
> 
> >I joined the list a few weeks back and, in good newsgroup style have
> >been reading through the correspondence to date. I don't think I've
> > ...
> >There's probably a book in there somewhere if someone had the energy
> >to write it...
> >
> Wow, that's dedication! I hope you don't mind if we all start asking you
> questions on stuff we can't recall :)

The dedication was in the reading - which was fun. The technology was
a Word macro (oh, and a VB program for grabbing the messages).

> >I've played around with various domains over time (XOR, OCR and some
> >simple games) but my most recent area of "research" has taken me back
> >to an old love betting on football matches (that's soccer to our
> I'm certainly interested in this, although I would imagine that the
> outcome of sporting events is even more unpredictable than financial
> markets. Having said that I see no reason to use the confidence output

No reason to use or no reason *not* to use? I was rather keen on the
confidence output - I thought for a while that it was going to be my
major contribution - until I read the messages discussing the idea on
this list...

> technique to pick up on any patterns that do occur, even if they only
> occur rarely. Hopefully the code underlying the fitness functions for
> these types of experiments will be transferable to different domains
> relatively easilty, so I see no reason to try investigate a whole range
> of domains.

Unpredictable yes, but estimation of likelihood is doable: I built an
Excel-based model that does a fair job of calculating odds. But not
good enough to be consistently profitable. And I don't know that the
method is actually valid because it's evolved as a population of one
with a mutation operator of dubious value (me).
 
> >non-UK colleagues). My interest has largely been rekindled by the rise
> >and rise of the betting exchanges, where the margin to be overcome is
> >
> Have you looked at spread betting at all? It gets (or has had) bad
> press, but there's no reason you should loose a lot of money if you're
> careful and know what you're doing. Just so long as you're not prone to
> compulsive gambling :)

The problem with spread betting is the lack of useful data for testing
against a profitability-based fitness function. Although simpler
markets such as total goals are probably doable. For most of the
spread markets I don't have data, or there aren't long enough
histories yet. I would dearly love, if only for personal amusement, to
see a total shirt number market traded successfully by NEAT.

For fixed-odds, however, I already have a good history of bookmakers
coupon odds - if a model can produce acceptable results against the
12% bookies' margin, then taking its selections to the exchanges ought
to be a no-brainer.

But it doesn't have to be hugely profitable (although I wouldn't say
no :-)) - it's the combination of  several areas of interest (GAs,
NNs, simulations, programming and footie) that makes the whole thing
fun.

> >I'm currently engaged (in between tasks associated with settling in to
> >a new house) in amusing myself with the consideration of various ways
> >of approaching my problem domain and familiarising myself with
> >existing NEAT implementations, Ken's "canonical" C++ and Colin's C# in
> >particular. I expect to "roll my own" code because as a professional
> >developer that's where much of the fun lies, and it's not like I'm in
> >any hurry.
> >
> OK well fire away if you have any questions on the C#.

I'm already working my way through SharpNEAT (lovely job, by the way).
I think the sensible approach is to build the model around your code
to start with and consider my wackier ideas later once that's all
running. I've followed the optimisation threads with great interest
(and learned a lot) - have you come across ArithEMITic
(http://blogs.geekdojo.net/richard/archive/2004/01/24/742.aspx)? It's
an approach that uses Reflection.Emit to compile the
performance-optimised code for a network on the fly. I don't claim to
understand it, and I don't suppose it would enhance something like
XOR, but larger models might benefit. Just in case you were suffering
from an excess of spare time...
> 
> Colin.

Regards,

Mike
